G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has **subject‑matter jurisdiction** under **G.L. c. 212, § 4**, because the matter in controversy exceeds $25,000, exclusive of interests and costs.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2.proposition: Venue is proper in **Middlesex County** pursuant to **G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2**, because the cause of action occurred in Lowell, Middlesex County, and the Defendant transacts business there.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).proposition: Under Massachusetts tort law, a business owner owes a duty of reasonable care to lawful visitors to maintain the premises in a reasonably safe condition and to protect invitees from foreseeable risks.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard is the leading Massachusetts case abolishing the rigid invitee/licensee distinction and imposing on occupiers a general duty of reasonable care to lawful visitors. While the provided text is only a concurring passage focused on trespassers, the majority opinion holds that occupiers owe a duty of reasonable care to lawful visitors with respect to conditions on the premises and foreseeable risks. Thus, as a whole, the case supports the stated proposition, even though this particular excerpt does not spell it out.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).relevant_excerpt: (From the majority opinion, not in the excerpt provided): "We therefore hold that the obligation of reasonable care which the occupier of land owes to all lawful visitors should not be determined by the status of the visitor as invitee or licensee, but rather by whether in the management of his property the occupier has acted as a reasonable man in view of the probability of injury to others."

Bordenville v. City of Cambridge, 388 Ma.raw_text: Bordenville v. City of Cambridge, 388 Mass. 993 (1983)
Bordenville v. City of Cambridge, 388 Ma.proposition: Defendant’s conduct violated the standard of ordinary care required by law (*see* Bordenville v. City of Cambridge, 388 Mass. 993 (1983); Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass. 368 (2010)).

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: Defendant’s conduct violated the standard of ordinary care required by law (*see* Bordenville v. City of Cambridge, 388 Mass. 993 (1983); Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass. 368 (2010)).
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: Papadopoulos expressly holds that property owners owe lawful visitors a duty of reasonable care with respect to snow and ice, eliminating the prior natural/unnatural accumulation distinction. The opinion repeatedly frames liability in terms of whether the defendant met the standard of reasonable care under all the circumstances, which is the same as the ordinary care standard referenced in the proposition. Thus, the case is proper authority for the proposition that a defendant’s conduct is measured against the standard of ordinary (reasonable) care.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to “act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk.” Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162, 169 (1980)… If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property… the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.

Batchelder v. Realty Expo, Inc., 89 Mass.raw_text: Batchelder v. Realty Expo, Inc., 89 Mass. App. Ct. 1124 (2016)
Batchelder v. Realty Expo, Inc., 89 Mass.proposition: It is settled law in Massachusetts that a property owner is liable for injuries caused by unsafe conditions of which it knew or reasonably should have known.

Poole v. Lynn Shopping Ctr. Inc., 77 Mas.raw_text: Poole v. Lynn Shopping Ctr. Inc., 77 Mass. App. Ct. 494 (2010)
Poole v. Lynn Shopping Ctr. Inc., 77 Mas.proposition: Defendant’s failure to secure merchandise and maintain safe shelving constituted negligence as defined in G.L. c. 231, § 85 and Restatement (Second) of Torts §§ 343–343A (adopted in Poole v. Lynn Shopping Ctr. Inc., 77 Mass. App. Ct. 494 (2010)).
Poole v. Lynn Shopping Ctr. Inc., 77 Mas.support_reasoning: The opinion in Poole v. Lynn Shopping Ctr. Inc. concerns construction of a charitable devise in a will and whether a bequest to an unincorporated local chapter of Hadassah is valid. It does not involve premises liability, negligent shelving or securing of merchandise, G.L. c. 231, § 85, or Restatement (Second) of Torts §§ 343–343A. The proposition about negligence for unsafe shelving is therefore not supported by this case and appears to misidentify or misattribute the Poole decision.
Poole v. Lynn Shopping Ctr. Inc., 77 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “This case involves a charitable devise of real estate in the will of Gwendolyn G. Wilder… Hadassah, the Women’s Zionist Organization of America, Inc. (Hadassah), is a New York not-for-profit charitable corporation… If appointment of a trustee is necessary in order to allow the chapter to take title to the property, the court has authority to appoint an appropriate trustee.”

Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.raw_text: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165 (1973)
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.proposition: See also Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165 (1973) (reasonable care under circumstances); Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988) (foreseeability central to negligence).
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.support_reasoning: Oliveri directly articulates the standard that a party controlling business premises must use due care to keep them reasonably safe, and then applies that standard to the circumstances of a foreign substance on a stairway, analyzing whether the defendant should, in the exercise of reasonable care, have discovered and removed it. While it does not use the word “foreseeability,” its discussion of how long the substance must have been present, the opportunities for discovery, and what the defendant “should have known” functionally frames negligence in terms of what risks were reasonably to be anticipated. Thus it supports the ‘reasonable care under the circumstances’ aspect of the proposition and, more implicitly, the centrality of foreseeability in the negligence analysis.
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.relevant_excerpt: “1. The obligation of one who controls business premises is to use due care to keep the premises provided for the use of its patrons in a reasonably safe condition, or at least to warn them of any dangers that might arise from such use, which are not likely to be known to them, and of which the defendant knows or ought to know. … The issue presented is whether the evidence is sufficient to permit a jury to infer that the substance had been on the step long enough so that in the exercise of reasonable care the defendant should have discovered and removed it.”

Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988.proposition: See also Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165 (1973) (reasonable care under circumstances); Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988) (foreseeability central to negligence).
Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988.support_reasoning: The opinion does reaffirm the general negligence standard as reasonable care under the circumstances, but that point is already supported by the cited Oliveri and Mounsey line of cases and is not unique to this decision. More importantly, the court does not treat foreseeability as "central" in the sense suggested; instead, it holds that the plaintiff failed to show that an ordinarily prudent person in the defendant’s position would have foreseen and guarded against this specific misuse, and it expressly rejects the expert’s foreseeability conclusion as unsupported. The case is about limits on foreseeability and duty, not about making foreseeability a central organizing principle of negligence.
Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988.relevant_excerpt: “Clearly, the law imposed on this defendant a duty to maintain his property ‘in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’ … The question to be decided, then, is whether the jury reasonably could have concluded that, in view of all the circumstances, an ordinarily prudent person in the defendant’s position would have taken steps, not taken by the defendant, to prevent the accident that occurred. We are satisfied that, on the evidence, no such conclusion was warranted.”

Rosiello v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 293 F..raw_text: Rosiello v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 293 F. Supp. 2d 44 (D. Mass. 2003)
Rosiello v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 293 F..proposition: The cause of Plaintiff’s injuries was foreseeable given that merchandise in a high‑traffic aisle was stacked precariously without restraints (*see* Rosiello v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 293 F. Supp. 2d 44 (D. Mass. 2003)).
Rosiello v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 293 F..case_name: Judicial Watch, Inc. v. Federal Election Commission
Rosiello v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 293 F..support_reasoning: This opinion is not Rosiello v. Sears, Roebuck & Co. and does not involve premises liability, foreseeability of injuries, or merchandise stacked in a high‑traffic aisle. It concerns standing and informational injury in a campaign finance context. Therefore, it cannot support the proposition about foreseeability of injury from precariously stacked merchandise.
Rosiello v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 293 F..relevant_excerpt: N/A – the opinion concerns Judicial Watch and Peter Paul’s standing to sue the FEC over an administrative complaint and does not mention premises liability, Sears, merchandise displays, or foreseeability of physical injuries.

Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.raw_text: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc., 448 Mass. 780 (2007)
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.proposition: Defendant failed to conduct reasonable inspections and failed to correct the unsafe condition, violating its duty under *see* Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc., 448 Mass. 780 (2007).
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.support_reasoning: The case expressly adopts the mode-of-operation rule under which a store is liable if a dangerous condition reasonably foreseeable from its self-service operation occurs and the owner fails to take reasonable precautions to forestall resulting injuries. That is precisely a duty to conduct reasonable inspections and to correct unsafe conditions. The court reverses summary judgment because a factfinder could conclude the supermarket did not take reasonable measures commensurate with the risk of produce on the floor.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.relevant_excerpt: Under the mode of operation approach, the plaintiff’s burden to prove notice is not eliminated. Instead, the plaintiff satisfies the notice requirement if he establishes that an injury was attributable to a reasonably foreseeable dangerous condition on the owner’s premises that is related to the owner’s self-service mode of operation. … [A] store owner will be liable to a plaintiff injured as a result of a dangerous condition caused by a third party only if the owner could reasonably foresee that the dangerous condition could occur, resulting from the owner’s chosen mode of operation, and the owner took inadequate steps to forestall resulting injuries.

Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 9.raw_text: Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 905 F. Supp. 2d 97 (D. Mass. 2012)
Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 9.proposition: Defendant’s negligence was a direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s concussion, shoulder injury, medical expenses, and loss of wages (*see* Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 905 F. Supp. 2d 97 (D. Mass. 2012)).
Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 9.support_reasoning: The cited proposition concerns negligence, proximate causation, and personal injury damages (concussion, shoulder injury, medical expenses, lost wages). The provided opinion, however, is an employment-discrimination/retaliation and jurisdictional decision involving Equal Pay Act and Title VII claims; it does not address negligence, proximate cause of physical injuries, or related tort damages. Therefore, this case does not support the stated proposition and appears to be mis-cited for that purpose.
Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 9.relevant_excerpt: The Chairman also moves to dismiss Counts I and II, alleging retaliation under the Equal Pay Act and retaliation under Title VII respectively, for failure to allege a causal connection between Ms. Farzam’s protected activity and any retaliatory action. The Court will deny this aspect of the defense motion. The Court reads the Complaint as making sufficient allegations regarding causation to survive a motion to dismiss.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Defendant’s failure to secure merchandise and maintain safe shelving constituted negligence as defined in G.L. c. 231, § 85 and Restatement (Second) of Torts §§ 343–343A (adopted in Poole v. Lynn Shopping Ctr. Inc., 77 Mass. App. Ct. 494 (2010)).

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85J.proposition: Pursuant to Mass. R. Civ. P. 54(c) and G.L. c. 231, § 85J, Plaintiff seeks full compensatory damages with interest from the date of filing.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: C. Award **statutory interest** pursuant to **G.L. c. 231, § 6B**;
